Table 3 Sample Quality (g) Oxygen absorption capacity (mmol) mmol/g Mn3O4 0.1 0.18 0.176 Ag/MnOx-0.5 0.1 0.22 0.215 Research Paper One-step synthesis of efficient silver-manganese catalyst with tunable dual active site content for formaldehyde removal at room temperature Jialu Tang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft a Haiping He Formal analysis a Xiaoqian Yang Formal analysis a Jinwei Chen Data curation a b ⁎ Ruilin Wang Formal analysis a b ⁎ a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China aCollege of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China b Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Chengdu 610065, China Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices Ministry of Education Chengdu 610065 China bEngineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Chengdu 610065, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Formaldehyde is one of the main pollutants in indoor air, and manganese-based oxides are the most promising catalysts for indoor catalytic oxidation to remove formaldehyde. In this work, Ag/MnOx catalysts with tunable dual active site content were synthesized by a simple one-step method and exhibited high formaldehyde removal performance at room temperature. Ag/MnOx-0.5 prepared from raw materials with a molar ratio of 0.5 has the highest catalytic activity. Under a static test at room temperature, Ag/MnOx-0.5 can remove 96 % of approximately 1 ppm HCHO in a 216 L glass box after 3 hours. Under dynamic test conditions of 150 L/(gcat h), Ag/MnOx-0.5 can maintain a formaldehyde removal rate of >80 % within 9 hours. The excellent catalytic activity of Ag/MnOx-0.5 at room temperature is mainly attributed to the surface Mn4+ and metallic Ag (Ag0) as active sites and its surface adsorbed oxygen with higher content and activity. This work provides a new preparation method for designing manganese-based oxide catalysts for indoor HCHO removal. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Formaldehyde removal Mn4+ Ag/MnOx Surface adsorbed oxygen Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, with the continuous improvement of living standards, people pay more and more attention to the indoor air quality issue. In particular, formaldehyde (HCHO) is one of the main pollutants in the indoor environment, and it mainly comes from furniture, decorative materials, building materials, and so on [1]. Formaldehyde is highly toxic, and long-term exposure to formaldehyde even at low concentrations can cause serious health problems such as skin allergies, neurasthenia, respiratory infections, and even cancer [2,3]. The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that the indoor HCHO concentration cannot exceed 0.1 mg/m3 (approximately 0.08 ppm). Therefore, many measures have been taken to remove indoor HCHO for human health, such as adsorption [4], plasma removal [5], ozone oxidation [6], photocatalytic oxidation [7,8], and catalytic oxidation [8]. The adsorption method for removing HCHO has the problems of limited adsorption capacity and secondary pollution caused by desorption. Although plasma removal, ozone oxidation, and photocatalytic oxidation methods can effectively remove HCHO, they will produce harmful by-products. However, catalytic oxidation for HCHO removal can convert HCHO into CO2 and H2O without the generation of harmful by-products. In addition, this method is low-cost and highly efficient. Therefore, catalytic oxidation is considered to be the most effective, green, and promising method [9,10]. The catalysts for catalytic oxidation of HCHO include supported noble metals (Pt, Ru, Ag, etc.) and transition metal oxides (MnOx, CeO2, Co3O4, etc.) [11–15]. Precious metal catalysts have high catalytic activity and can completely convert HCHO at room temperature, but the high price of precious metals has limited their development. Transition metal oxide catalysts are inexpensive and have high catalytic activity, so they have been widely studied. Among transition metal oxide catalysts, manganese oxide (MnOx) has been widely studied due to its excellent room-temperature catalytic activity, abundant resources, and environmental friendliness [16,17]. Zhou et al. [18] altered the surface oxygen vacancy concentration of α-MnO2 by hydrogen reduction treatment. The α-MnO2–2 h catalyst subjected to a 2 h hydrogen reduction treatment could achieve a complete conversion of 150 ppm HCHO at 70 °C. Ji et al. [19] prepared a series of δ-MnO2 by varying the concentration of K +. δ-MnO2 prepared with a medium concentration of K + had high surface oxygen concentration and high catalytic activity, which resulted in the complete removal of 22 ppm HCHO at 30 °C under a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 200,000 mL/(gcat h). Fang et al. [20] prepared a series of defective δ-MnO2 by reacting KMnO4 with different reductants (methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol). Among them, the MnO2-Iso catalyst prepared with isopropanol as reductant showed the best catalytic activity for HCHO. The conversion efficiency of the MnO2-Iso towards 80 ppm of HCHO was 90 % at 30 °C under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 120 L/(gcat h). Bai et al. [21] prepared 3D-MnO2 using KIT-6 mesoporous molecular sieve as a hard template. At 130 °C, 3D-MnO2 can completely remove HCHO, mainly because a large amount of Mn4+ on the catalyst surface can provide sufficient active sites for oxidizing HCHO. More surface Mn4+ can increase the oxygen vacancies of the oxide, which is beneficial to the adsorption, activation and migration of oxygen in the gas phase [22]. Currently, most MnOx catalysts of HCHO removal in reported works are prepared by using KMnO4 as precursor. KMnO4 is a strong oxidant that releases a lot of heat during the reaction, and there is a risk of explosion when it is prepared in large quantities. Therefore, there is a need to find manganese compounds that can replace KMnO4 for the preparation of MnOx catalysts under mild and safe conditions. Since manganese acetate can be oxidized by oxygen in an alkaline solution to generate Mn3O4, manganese acetate can be used as a precursor to prepare manganese-based oxide catalysts with high Mn4+ active site content. Adding noble metal catalysts to manganese-based oxides can also further improve the activity of the catalyst. Fang et al. [23] prepared Ag@Ag2O-MnOx composite nanowires by electrospinning, thermal calcination, and KMnO4 solution post-treatment, and the catalysts exhibited high efficiency in the removal of HCHO. The removal efficiency of Ag@Ag2O-MnOx catalyst reached 93.7 % after catalytic oxidation of HCHO for 3 h at room temperature, which was mainly due to the interaction between Ag/AgO2 and MnO2 as well as the high specific surface area and a large amount of active oxygen of the catalyst. Hu et al. [24] prepared Ag/MnO2 by hydrothermal and calcination and then activated it with different gases (H2, CO), among which Ag/Mn-CO showed high catalytic activity. Ag/Mn-CO can convert 90 % of HCHO into CO2 at 100 °C, which is mainly because the metallic silver with appropriate particle size can serve as active sites to convert adsorbed oxygen into active oxygen and then remove formaldehyde. Therefore, both Mn4+ and Ag0 can serve as active sites to remove formaldehyde and the interaction between the two can improve the catalytic activity of manganese-based catalysts. Currently, silver-manganese catalysts are mainly prepared by hydrothermal and calcination methods. Therefore, in order to be more conducive to actual production, it is necessary to develop a more energy-saving, simple and safe preparation method. In this work, a new one-step synthetic method was developed under mild and safe conditions to prepare efficient manganese-based oxide catalyst with tunable Mn4+ and Ag0 contents. Manganese acetate (Mn(CH3COO)2) and silver nitrate (AgNO3) were added to the alkaline solution and reacted at room temperature for 30 min to obtain Ag/MnOx catalyst, which was used for catalytic oxidation of HCHO at room temperature, showing excellent catalytic activity. When the molar ratio of AgNO3 and Mn(CH3COO)2 was 0.5, the synthesized Ag/MnOx-0.5 had the highest catalytic activity and stability. A series of characterizations revealed that the reaction process produced Mn4+ and Ag0, and the synthesized Ag/MnOx-0.5 had a higher content and activity of surface adsorbed oxygen, resulting in Ag/MnOx-0.5 having excellent catalytic activity at room temperature. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Manganese acetate (Mn(CH3COO)2), silver nitrate (AgNO3), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from China Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd. Formaldehyde solution was purchased from Chengdu Jinshan Chemical Reagent Co. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Mn3O4 As shown in Fig. 1 , 0.4844 g Mn(CH3COO)2 was put into a 100 mL beaker, and then 80 mL of deionized water was added and dissolved by stirring at room temperature to obtain a clear colorless solution. Then, 0.5 g NaOH was added, and the solution immediately turned into a brown solution. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 min to obtain a brown precipitate of Mn3O4. Filter the brown precipitate and wash it three times with deionized water, then dry it in an oven at 70 °C for 24 hours. 2.2.2 Ag/MnOx As shown in Fig. 1, 0.4844 g Mn(CH3COO)2 was put into a 100 mL beaker, and then 80 mL of deionized water was added and dissolved by stirring at room temperature to obtain a clear colorless solution. Then 0.5 g NaOH was added and stirred for 2 min. Then AgNO3 was added and the solution immediately turned black. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 min to obtain a black precipitate. The black precipitate was filtered and washed three times with deionized water, and then dried in an oven at 70 °C for 24 hours. The catalysts prepared using the molar ratios of AgNO3 and Mn(CH3COO)2 of 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, and 1 were named Ag/MnOx-0.1, Ag/MnOx-0.3, Ag/MnOx-0.5, Ag/MnOx-0.7, and Ag/MnOx-1, respectively. 2.3 Characterization The crystal structure of the catalyst was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). XRD tests were performed using a Japanese Rigaku Ultima IV instrument. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) was used to determine the surface functional groups of the catalyst. FTIR was performed using a Japanese Shimadzu-IRTracer-100 instrument. The morphology of the catalyst was determined using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM). FESEM used a German ZEISS sigma500, and TEM used a Japanese JEOL-JEM 2100 F. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the catalyst to explore the surface chemistry of the sample. XPS used an American ThermoFisher ESCALAB Xi+ and was analyzed using XPS peak software. ICP-OES was performed on an Agilent 7850. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrometry (DRIFTS) was performed using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer. Oxygen temperature-program desorption (O2-TPD) was performed on a Japanese BelCata II instrument, and the specific test methods can be found in the supporting information. 2.4 Catalytic activity experiments Both static and dynamic tests were used to simulate the removal of formaldehyde at room temperature. The static test was conducted in a 216 L glass box at room temperature. First, 100 mg of catalyst was loaded into a petri dish and sealed with plastic wrap. The petri dish was placed at the bottom of the glass box, and the glass box was sealed with vacuum silicone. A hose with a certain amount of formaldehyde solution (36–38 %) was placed into the glass box through the hole on the top of the glass box. The formaldehyde was evenly dispersed using a fan inside the glass box. A fixed HCHO detector (JSA5-CH2O-A, 0–10 ppm) was used to monitor the HCHO concentration in real time. When the HCHO concentration stabilized at ∼1 ppm, the plastic wrap on the petri dish was removed and the HCHO concentration began to be recorded regularly. The HCHO removal rate can be calculated using the following formula: (1) HCHO removal ( % ) = HCH O 0 − HCH O t HCH O 0 Where HCHO0 is the initial HCHO concentration and HCHOt is the HCHO concentration at a certain time. For the dynamic test, 200 mg of catalyst was placed in a quartz tube with 10 mm diameter, and N2 was used to pass through the diluted formaldehyde solution at room temperature to generate HCHO gas by bubbling. In order to simulate the air environment, O2 was introduced and the gas flow rate was adjusted to form a mixed gas containing 79 % N2 and 21 % O2. The HCHO concentration was controlled at about 1 ppm at the inlet, the mixed gas flow rate was 500 mL/min, the gas hourly space velocity was 150 L g −1h−1, and the RH was 55 %. The MBTH (3-methyl-2-benzothiazoline hydrazine) method [25,26] was used to test the concentration of HCHO at the inlet and outlet, and the formaldehyde removal rate can be calculated by the following formula: (2) HCHO removal ( % ) = HCH O inlet − HCH O outlet HCH O inlet Where HCHOinlet and HCHOoutlet represent the inlet and outlet concentrations of HCHO, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties The phase structure and crystal structure of Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 were investigated by XRD (Fig. 2a ). The diffraction peaks of Mn3O4 show a typical manganese tetraoxide structure (PDF#80–0328). The diffraction peaks of Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 at 38.1°, 44.3°, 64.4°, 77.4° and 81.5° are consistent with the diffraction peaks of metallic Ag (Ag0) (PDF#99–0094), indicating that Ag+ is reduced to Ag0. The characteristic peaks of Mn3O4 corresponding to Ag/MnOx-0.5 are weakened, and those of Ag/MnOx-1 disappeared, indicating that the addition of silver leads to structural modifications in these catalysts. The composition of the surface functional groups of Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 was analyzed by FTIR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 2b, the peaks at 491 cm−1 and 610 cm−1 are the Mn-O bonds of the MnO6 structure, further confirming that the catalysts are manganese oxides [27,28]. The broad absorption band at 3383 cm−1 belongs to the OH stretching vibration peak [29], which shows that there is no OH group in Ag/MnOx before the reaction. The microstructures of the catalysts were observed using SEM and TEM. SEM and magnified SEM images are shown in Fig. 3a –c and Figure S1. Mn3O4 is composed of particles <100 nm. Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 are composed of nanoparticles and nanosheets formed by the agglomeration of nanoparticles. In addition, compared with Ag/MnOx-0.5, Ag/MnOx-1 has more sheet-like nanoclusters, which indicates that the more silver content in the catalyst, the smaller the nanoparticles and the more nanoparticles agglomerations. From the mapping test of Fig. 3d, it can be observed that the Ag, Mn, and O elements in the Ag/MnOx-0.5 catalyst are uniformly distributed. TEM images of Ag/MnOx-0.5 are shown in Fig. 4a –c. From Fig. 4a, it can be seen that Ag/MnOx-0.5 exists in a loose form, and from Fig. 4b, c, it can be seen that lattice spacings of 0.236 nm and 0.249 nm can be identified in the grains, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of Ag0 and the (211) crystal plane of Mn3O4, respectively, which further confirms the results of XRD. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5a . The isotherms of Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 are all type IV curves, and when P/P0>0.4, H3 type hysteresis loops appear, indicating that they are all mesoporous structures [30]. As can be seen from Fig. 5b, the pore diameter of Mn3O4 is mainly concentrated around 20 nm, the pore diameter of Ag/MnOx-0.5 is mainly concentrated around 30 nm, and the pore diameter of Ag/MnOx-1 is mainly concentrated around 10 nm. Table 1 summarizes the results of the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the catalyst. Ag/MnOx-0.5 has the largest specific surface area, pore volume and pore size. The pore sizes of Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 are 31.24 nm and 12.54 nm, respectively. It can be seen that excessive silver will reduce the pore size of the catalyst, which may be because part of the pores are occupied by Ag0 [31–33]. Small pore size is not conducive to the diffusion of HCHO, resulting in weakened catalytic activity. Therefore, Ag/MnOx-0.5 is better than Ag/MnOx-1 in the HCHO removal performance test (Fig. 7). The surface chemical state of the catalysts was analyzed by XPS test. The Ag 3d spectra are shown in Fig. 6a . Ag/MnOx-0.5 shows spin-orbit double peaks at 368.4 eV (Ag 3d5/2) and 374.4 eV (Ag 3d3/2), and Ag/MnOx-1 shows spin-orbit double peaks at 368.1 eV (Ag 3d5/2) and 374.1 eV (Ag 3d3/2), indicating that they both have Ag0 [34–37]. Ag/MnOx-0.5 is overall red-shifted by 0.3 eV relative to Ag/MnOx-1, which may be because the increase in silver content enhances the interaction between Ag0 and MnOx, which involves the transfer of electrons, thereby changing the inherent electronic environment of the catalyst [38,39]. Ag0 can serve as an active site for formaldehyde oxidation reaction and remove HCHO by activating surface oxygen [40]. The Mn 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 6b The peaks located at approximately 640.6 eV, 642.0 eV and 643.0 eV correspond to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [41]. From Table 2 , it can be found that compared with Mn3O4, the Mn2+ content of Ag/MnOx decreases and Mn4+ content increases, which implies that the addition of silver has caused an electron loss process (Mn2+→Mn4+). The electron loss can enhance the adsorption of O2, leading to the activation of adsorbed O2 in the form of OA and Olatt on the catalyst surface [42,43]. In addition, Ag/MnOx has more Mn4+ content, which means more Mn4+ is exposed to the catalyst surface. The large amount of Mn4+ provides sufficient active sites for the HCHO oxidation reaction [22,44]. In addition, we used ICP-OES to determine the actual composition of the catalyst, as shown in the Table S1. The actual composition of Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 is almost the same, indicating that even if the input amount of AgNO3 is increased, the Ag content in the catalyst does not increase. This may be because Ag+ is loaded on Mn3O4 to oxidize Mn2+ to Mn4+ and form Ag0 at the same time. When the raw material molar ratio is 0.5, the loading site reaches saturation, so when the ratio is increased, the actual content of Ag and Mn does not change. Therefore, Ag/MnOx-0.5 prepared with a raw material molar ratio of 0.5 is the optimal composition of the catalyst. The Mn 3 s spectra are shown in Fig. 6c. The splitting widths (ΔE) of Mn 3 s for Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5, and Ag/MnOx-1 are 5.6 eV, 5.4 eV, and 4.9 eV, respectively. The average oxidation state (AOS) is usually calculated based on the value of ΔE according to the following equation: AOS = 8.956–1.126*ΔE [45]. The AOS values for different catalysts are Ag/MnOx-1 (3.40) > Ag/MnOx-0.5 (2.88) > Mn3O4 (2.60). It can be seen that the AOS values of the catalysts follow the same trend as the ratio of Mn4+. According to Figure S2 and Table S2, Ag/MnOx-0.1 with a low silver content also contains Ag0 and Mn4+. Compared with Mn3O4, the Mn2+ content of Ag/MnOx-0.1 does not change much, but the Mn3+ content is greatly reduced. Therefore, when the silver content is low, the main transformation occurs from Mn3+ to Mn4+. In addition, it can be seen from Table 2 and Table S2 that the Mn4+ content of the catalyst is positively correlated with the molar ratio of the raw materials. The O 1 s spectra are shown in Fig. 6d The peaks at binding energies of approximately 529.5 eV, 531.5 eV and 532.7 eV correspond to lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface hydroxyl group (OH) and surface adsorbed oxygen (OA), respectively [46]. It can be seen from Fig. 6d that Mn3O4 has surface hydroxyl groups, but Ag/MnOx does not, which is consistent with the characteristic peaks in the FTIR spectrum where only Mn3O4 has hydroxyl groups. The value of OH/Olatt for Mn3O4 is 0.28, OA/Olatt for Ag/MnOx-0.5 is 0.37, and OA/Olatt for Ag/MnOx-1 is 0.47. The larger the OA/Olatt value and OH/Olatt value, the more favorable it is for catalytic oxidation to remove HCHO. Although Ag/MnOx-1 has the largest content of Mn4+ and OA, Ag/MnOx-1 is lower than Ag/MnOx-0.5 in the catalytic performance test, which is because pore size diameter is smaller than that of Ag/MnOx-0.5, thus reducing the catalytic activity. 3.2 Performance of HCHO oxidation Fig. 7 shows the catalytic activity of Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5, and Ag/MnOx-1 for HCHO at room temperature. The prepared catalysts (∼100 mg) were evaluated for low-concentration formaldehyde (∼1 ppm) removal activity by static testing at room temperature (RH = 55 %) by simulating the indoor environment, and the results are shown in Fig. 7a. Since the static test was carried out in a glass box, the effect of the glass box on the adsorption of HCHO was investigated. Under the same static test conditions, a blank experiment without catalysts was conducted. As shown in Figure S4, within 3 hours, the formaldehyde concentration dropped very little, so it can be seen that the glass box has a weak adsorption capacity for formaldehyde and has little effect on the entire static test process. Therefore, the effect of adsorption on the inner wall of the glass box on the catalyst performance can be ruled out during the static test. As shown in Fig. 7a, after 3 hours, the HCHO removal efficiencies of Ag/MnOx-0.5 and Ag/MnOx-1 reached 96.36 % and 86.49 %, respectively, but the HCHO removal efficiency of Mn3O4 was only 33.03 %. It can be seen that the catalytic activity of Ag/MnOx is significantly higher than that of Mn3O4. In addition, the HCHO removal efficiency of Ag/MnOx prepared with a series of different molar ratios of AgNO3 and Mn(CH3COO)2 was further studied, and the results are shown in Figure S4. The HCHO removal efficiencies of Ag/MnOx prepared with molar ratios of 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 and 1 were 79.9 %, 92.59 %, 96.36 %, 89.65 % and 86.49 %, respectively. Although the removal efficiency of Ag/MnOx-0.1 is the lowest, it is significantly higher than that of Mn3O4, which indicates that the addition of a small amount of silver can significantly improve the HCHO catalytic activity of the Ag/MnOx catalyst. In order to reveal the kinetics of the catalytic process, a pseudo-first order model was used: (3) k = − ln HCH O t HCH O 0 In the equation, k is the pseudo-first-order reaction rate constant and t is the reaction time. The linear fitting data of the model are shown in the Fig. 7b The correlation coefficient (R2) shows that the degradation of HCHO in the static test conforms to the pseudo-first order reaction kinetics. The reaction rate constants of Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5, and Ag/MnOx-1 are 0.0023min−1, 0.0169min−1, and 0.0116min−1, respectively. It can be seen that the reaction rate constant of Ag/MnOx is significantly larger than that of Mn3O4. Among a series of Ag/MnOx catalysts, the HCHO removal efficiency of Ag/MnOx-0.5 prepared at a ratio of 0.5 is the highest. In order to investigate the lifetime of Ag/MnOx-0.5, a cyclic static test was performed (see Supplementary Material for details of the test methods). As shown in Fig. 7c, after 5 cycling tests, Ag/MnOx-0.5 still has good catalytic activity. In the fifth cycle test, Ag/MnOx-0.5 showed the HCHO removal efficiency of 73.15 %, which indicates that Ag/MnOx-0.5 has good cycling stability performance. In addition, we also evaluated the catalytic activity of Ag/MnOx-0.5 for 1 ppm HCHO at room temperature and different humidity conditions. Under the three humidity conditions, the formaldehyde removal efficiencies of Ag/MnOx-0.5 after 3 hours were 93.52 %, 94.90 %, and 96.36 %, respectively. Therefore, Ag/MnOx-0.5 can show excellent catalytic activity under different humidity conditions. In order to evaluate the adsorption, mass transfer and catalytic activity of the catalysts for HCHO at room temperature and high air velocity, continuous dynamic tests were carried out on Mn3O4, Ag/MnOx-0.5 in a simulated air purifier mode. As shown in Fig. 7d, when the space velocity was 150 L/(gcat h) and about 1 ppm HCHO was continuously introduced, the catalytic activity of Mn3O4 was <20 % within 1.5 h, while Ag/MnOx-0.5 could maintain a formaldehyde removal rate of >80 % within 9 h, which indicates that Ag/MnOx-0.5 has good catalytic activity and stability in dynamic tests. Based on the above results, it can be seen that compared with Mn3O4, the catalytic activity of Ag/MnOx catalysts is significantly improved, among which Ag/MnOx-0.5 shows the best catalytic activity and good cyclability and stability. As shown in Table S3, the hydrothermal temperature is generally 100–200 °C, and the calcination temperature is generally 300–400 °C. This work is prepared by reaction at room temperature. It can be seen that the preparation method of this work consumes much less energy than the hydrothermal and calcination methods, and is also safer and simpler. In addition, compared with the existing literature (Table S4), it can be seen from the removal of HCHO activity and reaction rate constant that the catalyst prepared in this work also has excellent catalytic activity. Ag/MnOx-0.5 has the advantages of simple synthesis, mild and safe preparation conditions, high catalytic activity, good cyclic performance, and good stability, so it has great application prospects in removing HCHO in indoor environments. 3.3 Mechanism of HCHO removal In order to understand the mechanism of catalytic oxidative removal of formaldehyde by Ag/MnOx-0.5, we performed O2-TPD and in-situ DRIFTS. The oxygen desorption behavior and reactivity of Mn3O4 and Ag/MnOx-0.5 catalysts were investigated using O2-TPD. In the Fig. 8 the desorption peaks below 300 °C are attributed to surface chemisorbed oxygen, and the desorption peaks at 300–600 °C can be attributed to subsurface lattice oxygen [47]. The desorption peaks at lower temperatures for Ag/MnOx-0.5 compared to Mn3O4 indicate that it has higher surface adsorbed oxygen mobility and reactivity, which facilitates the oxidation of HCHO at room temperature. As shown in Table 3 , Ag/MnOx-0.5 has more surface adsorbed oxygen and therefore is more favorable for the oxidation of HCHO. We used in-situ DRIFTS at room temperature to analyze the intermediates and final products of HCHO reaction on Ag/MnOx-0.5. As shown in the Fig. 9 , as the reaction proceeds, a series of characteristic peaks appear. The peak at 3565 cm−1 corresponds to the surface hydroxyl group (OH), and the peak at 2363 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of CO2 [44,48]. The peak at 1263 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of dioxymethylene (DOM), which is the initial intermediate of HCHO oxidation [49]. The peaks at 1540 cm−1 and 1685 cm−1 correspond to the characteristic peaks of formate [48,49]. No peaks related to adsorbed HCHO were found on the catalyst, indicating that the adsorbed HCHO was rapidly oxidized on the catalyst surface. As the reaction proceeds, the peaks of DOM and formate species on the catalyst surface gradually increase, indicating that they gradually accumulate on the catalyst surface and may cover some of the active sites on the surface, resulting in a decrease in catalytic performance [50]. The process of catalytic oxidation of HCHO on metal oxide catalysts conforms to the Mars-Van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [51]. Combined with the characterization results, the O2 molecules adsorbed on the Ag0 and Mn4+ sites are activated and called active oxygen atoms (O*). O* contributes to the conversion of HCHO to DOM and then to HCOO−. HCOO− is dehydrogenated again by O* to generate CO2 and H2O. The generated H2O may be converted into hydroxyl groups, which will also promote the oxidation reaction of formaldehyde. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Ag/MnOx catalyst with tunable dual active site content was prepared by a one-step synthesis method under mild and safe conditions, and it was confirmed that their catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde conformed to the pseudo-first order model. Among them, Ag/MnOx-0.5 had the best catalytic activity, which is mainly because Ag/MnOx-0.5 has Mn4+ and Ag0 as active sites to promote the oxidation of HCHO, and had a higher content and activity of surface adsorbed oxygen. The pseudo-first order fitting results showed that the reaction rate constant k of Ag/MnOx-0.5 was 0.0169 min−1, indicating that the catalyst could efficiently drive the HCHO oxidation reaction at room temperature. Ag/MnOx-0.5 maintained excellent removal efficiency and cyclic stability under static and dynamic conditions. The Ag/MnOx catalyst provides a new preparation method under mild and safe conditions for designing manganese-based oxide catalysts for indoor HCHO removal. coredata.dc:description: Formaldehyde is one of the main pollutants in indoor air, and manganese-based oxides are the most promising catalysts for indoor catalytic oxidation to remove formaldehyde. In this work, Ag/MnOx catalysts with tunable dual active site content were synthesized by a simple one-step method and exhibited high formaldehyde removal performance at room temperature. Ag/MnOx-0.5 prepared from raw materials with a molar ratio of 0.5 has the highest catalytic activity. Under a static test at room temperature, Ag/MnOx-0.5 can remove 96 % of approximately 1 ppm HCHO in a 216 L glass box after 3 hours. Under dynamic test conditions of 150 L/(gcat h), Ag/MnOx-0.5 can maintain a formaldehyde removal rate of >80 % within 9 hours. The excellent catalytic activity of Ag/MnOx-0.5 at room temperature is mainly attributed to the surface Mn4+ and metallic Ag (Ag0) as active sites and its surface adsorbed oxygen with higher content and activity. This work provides a new preparation method for designing manganese-based oxide catalysts for indoor HCHO removal.
